resources.string: Thirty Days of Security
Strong passwords for online accounts
Use unique and robust passwords to protect your online accounts from unauthorized access.
Enable two-factor authentication (2FA)
Add an extra layer of security to your accounts by enabling two-factor authentication, which requires a verification code in addition to your password.
Keep software up to date
Regularly update your operating system, browser, and antivirus software to ensure you have the latest security patches and protection against vulnerabilities.
Be cautious with online sharing
Exercise caution when sharing personal information online, particularly on social media platforms, to safeguard your privacy and prevent potential misuse.
Avoid clicking unknown links
Refrain from clicking on links in emails or messages from unfamiliar sources to avoid falling victim to phishing attempts or malware downloads.
Beware of information requests
Stay skeptical of emails or messages requesting personal or financial information, as they could be scams attempting to steal your sensitive data.
Download from trusted sources
Only download files or applications from reputable sources to minimize the risk of inadvertently installing malware or harmful software.
Use firewall and antivirus
Protect your devices by utilizing firewalls and reliable antivirus software to shield against unauthorized access and potential security threats.
Regularly back up data
Create regular backups of your important files and data to prevent data loss in case of device theft, hardware failure, or other unforeseen events.
Be cautious of Wi-Fi networks
Exercise caution when connecting to Wi-Fi networks, particularly public ones, to avoid potential risks associated with unsecured networks.
Avoid sensitive activities on public computers
Refrain from performing sensitive activities, such as accessing financial accounts, on public computers that may not be secure and could compromise your information.
Be aware of public Wi-Fi risks
Understand the risks associated with using public Wi-Fi, such as the potential for data interception or unauthorized access to your device, and take appropriate precautions.
Use VPN on public Wi-Fi
Enhance your online security on public Wi-Fi by using a virtual private network (VPN) to encrypt your internet connection and protect your data.
Secure devices when not in use
Take measures to secure your devices when you\'re not actively using them, such as locking them with passwords or biometric authentication.
Guard against device theft
Prevent device theft by not leaving your devices unattended in public places and keeping them secure to protect your personal information.
Be careful with phone information
Exercise caution when sharing personal information over the phone to avoid potential scams or fraudulent activities.
Avoid giving personal information to strangers
Refrain from disclosing your personal information to individuals you don\'t know or trust to protect yourself from identity theft or other risks.
Beware of social engineering
Stay vigilant about social engineering attacks, where individuals manipulate or deceive others into revealing sensitive information, and be cautious of such attempts.
Report suspicious activity
If you encounter any suspicious or potentially illegal activity, report it to the relevant authorities to help maintain a safer online environment.
Stay updated on security threats
Stay informed about the latest security threats and vulnerabilities to take necessary precautions and protect your devices and data.
Keep devices in good working order
Maintain the functionality of your devices by performing regular maintenance and addressing any software or hardware issues promptly.
Be selective with app installations
Exercise caution when installing apps and choose them selectively to minimize the risk of downloading malicious or intrusive applications.
Trustworthy sources for app downloads
Only download apps from trusted sources, such as official app stores, to reduce the likelihood of installing compromised or harmful applications.
Review app privacy policies
Before installing an app, review its privacy policy to understand what data it collects, how it\'s used, and ensure it aligns with your privacy preferences.
Be mindful of data sharing
Be mindful of the information you share with apps, ensuring it\'s necessary and limited to protect your privacy and prevent potential data misuse.
Risks of mobile malware
Be aware of the risks associated with mobile malware, such as malicious apps or software targeting mobile devices, and take precautions to protect yourself.
Secure mobile devices when idle
Take measures to secure your mobile devices when they\'re not in use, such as using passcodes or biometric authentication, to prevent unauthorized access.
Prevent mobile device theft
Avoid leaving your mobile devices unattended in public places to minimize the risk of theft, which could lead to unauthorized access to your personal information.
Use mobile security apps
Enhance the security of your mobile devices by using reputable mobile security apps that provide features like antivirus protection and anti-theft capabilities.
Regularly back up mobile data
Regularly create backups of your mobile data, including contacts, photos, and important files, to safeguard against data loss or device failure.
